newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albanian president admits mistakes amid protests.
newsitem.headline: Albanian president admits mistakes amid protests.

text.p: Albanians who lost their life savings when pyramid investment schemes collapsed planned fresh protests on Sunday after President Sali Berisha admitted the government made mistakes in handling the crisis.
The main opposition alliance, the Forum for Democracy, urged people to attend a mass rally in Tirana although it did not have an official permit for the demonstration.
Berisha, in his first real explanation for the scandal, blamed the government, the opposition parties and "those who chose" to all their money into high-risk schemes -- and lost everything.
Thousands of people attended rallies across Albania on Saturday to demand reimbursement and call for the right-wing government of Prime Minister Aleksander Meksi to resign.

But Berisha sternly told the public, who emerged from 45 years of isolation and Stalinism only in 1990, that they had learned a hard lesson in free market economics and would get no cash from the government.
"We will not take this debt on our shoulders. No democratic government would do this. It would be cheating, printing money to pay and creating hyperinflation", he said.
The Forum for Democracy's call for a mass rally in Tirana came after riot police blocked earlier demonstrations in the capital, confining anti-government protests largely to the provinces.
Protesters marched peacefully in the southern towns of Vlore, Fier, Tepelene and Permet on Saturday, chanting: "Down with government, president and parliament" and "We want our money."
"We would not stop until the government resigns and the ruined and robbed people are free," said Halit Gjoni, an opposition socialist deputy.
In Fier, police stepped aside and let thousands of angry investors march. In Vlore, the scene of bloody clashes last Monday, people demonstrated for a 12th day.
A senior police commander, who declined to be named, said: "There is no problem. We have withdrawn the riot police. Let them demonstrate. It's their right."
Vlore has seen some of the most serious violence since the popular high-risk investment schemes began collapsing in January.
Berisha acknowledged that many Albanians were now homeless because they sold their houses to pump money into schemes which promised to pay interest of 60 percent or more a month.
Bankers estimate that $1 to $2 billion may have been poured into dodgy schemes, five of which have gone bust in the past month.

Anti-government protests and riots have swept Albania, Europe's poorest country, since the schemes began to fail in January. Several people have been killed and hundreds have been injured or arrested.
Berisha pleaded that the government had been naive and was new to democracy and capitalism. He appealed to all parties to join in trying to sort out the mess.
But, in a thinly-veiled reference, he blasted the main opposition Socialist Party, the former communists, for trying to exploit the confusion for political advantage.

"Today, at a time when hundreds of thousands of Albanians are suffering from losses in pyramid schemes, a minority...wants to turn this big, but not irreparable, loss into a real national tragedy," he said.
